dt.t: omit details that are not {wi}germane{/wi} to the discussion

pt: {sc}relevant{/sc} {sc}germane{/sc} {sc}material{/sc} {sc}pertinent{/sc} {sc}apposite{/sc} {sc}applicable{/sc} {sc}apropos{/sc} mean relating to or bearing upon the matter in hand. {sc}relevant{/sc} implies a traceable, significant, logical connection.
{sc}germane{/sc} may additionally imply a fitness for or appropriateness to the situation or occasion.

pt.t: a point not {it}germane{/it} to the discussion

pt: {sc}material{/sc} implies so close a relationship that it cannot be dispensed with without serious alteration of the case.
{sc}pertinent{/sc} stresses a clear and decisive relevance.

pt.t: add an {it}apposite{/it} quotation to the definition

pt: {sc}applicable{/sc} suggests the fitness of bringing a general rule or principle to bear upon a particular case.

pt.t: the rule is not {it}applicable{/it} in this case

pt: {sc}apropos{/sc} suggests being both relevant and opportune.

quotes.t: From time to time, engineers and scientists hold conferences … where they trot out ideas they have developed, frequently ideas {qword}germane{/qword} to solving practical problems.
The press material for this film contains some notes made by the Dardenne brothers during the shooting. Such material is usually disposable, but these notes are {qword}germane.{/qword}.
Bork and his supporters argued that his "academic" writings and his speeches were not {qword}germane{/qword} to whether he should be confirmed.

et: Middle English {it}germain{/it}, literally, having the same parents, from Anglo-French
shortdef: being at once relevant and appropriate : fitting
